Schema Validation Failures With Detailed Error Codes: While malformed XML is covered, there are no scenarios that assert specific schema validation failure messages for missing/invalid catalog fields (e.g., missing required XML elements vs generic malformed XML).

Idempotency / Repeated Identical Requests: While duplicate version is addressed, there is no explicit test for safely retrying identical POSTs in flight or client retries behavior (idempotency concerns).

Transactional/Atomicity Guarantees: No tests validate partial application guarantees on complex payloads (e.g., if part of XML contains multiple entities and one fails, ensure no partial catalog version created).

Response Content-Type and Schema: Tests assert presence of confirmation string/Location header but do not validate response Content-Type (text/plain vs application/json) or structure of the confirmation payload.
Exact Location header semantics: Presence is tested (TC01/TC02) but no validation of correctness of the URL format, accessibility or that it resolves to the new resource.
Rate Limiting / Throttling Behavior: Although performance tests exist, there are no tests that verify enforcement of rate limits or proper 429 handling.
Caching / Headers: No tests for caching headers or ETag/Cache-Control semantics (not strictly required for POST but may be relevant for resource URL responses).

Authorization Scope/Role-based Access Controls: TC14 tests missing/invalid auth, but there are no scenarios testing role-based permission (e.g., user with read-only token) or fine-grained authorization failures.
Content-Encoding and Transfer-Encoding: No tests for chunked transfer encoding, gzip compressed payloads, or other transfer encodings that could affect parsing.
recommendations: Add an explicit 500 Internal Server Error scenario (simulate DB exception/unhandled error) to ensure the API surfaces 500 and does not leak sensitive info.

Create schema validation negative tests that submit well-formed XML which violates catalog business rules (e.g., missing product id, invalid price format) and assert specific validation errors (distinct from generic malformed-XML 400).
Add idempotency/retry scenarios: repeated identical POSTs and client retry after timeout to verify duplicate handling and safe retries.
Add transactional integrity tests: submit XML with multiple entities where one entity is invalid and assert that no partial catalog is persisted.
Assert response Content-Type and structure: verify that the confirmation body is returned in expected content-type (text/plain or application/json) and, if JSON, validate expected keys/values.
Enhance Location header assertions: validate format, version identifier, and optionally do a follow-up GET to ensure the Location URL resolves to the created catalog version.
Add rate-limiting tests to assert 429 responses when request rates exceed configured limits and verify headers (Retry-After) if applicable.
Add role-based authorization scenarios to ensure only permitted roles can upload catalogs and unauthorized role returns 403.
Add tests for chunked/streamed uploads and compressed payloads to ensure parser robustness for different transfer encodings.
Include tests that verify handling of various Content-Encodings and that the server rejects unsupported encodings with appropriate status codes.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/allCustomFields - Retrieve account customFields

covered: Valid Request: Several scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03–TC05, TC08–TC09, TC11, TC29–TC31) verify successful responses (HTTP 200) for valid accountId and combinations of query parameters.
Empty Response: TC06 and TC07 explicitly cover accounts with no custom fields and filters that return empty arrays.
Query Parameters: Positive and negative parameter cases are tested (objectType enums in TC02, TC08; audit levels in TC03, TC04, TC09; unsupported/extra params in TC10; invalid formats in TC32, TC36).
Authorization / Authentication: TC14 and TC15 test missing and invalid authentication resulting in 401 responses.

Input Validation & Error Handling: TC12, TC13, TC17, TC32–TC36 cover invalid accountId format, non-existent account (404), SQL/XSS attempts, unexpected types, overly long or empty IDs, and whitespace issues, ensuring the API validates inputs and does not leak sensitive data.

Resilience / Recovery: TC16, TC19, TC20, TC39 and integration/regression cases (TC21, TC23) exercise service unavailability, timeouts, retries, dependency failures and regression behavior for audit handling.
Performance / Load: TC11 (large dataset), TC25, TC26 address large datasets, concurrency and resource utilization under load.
Edge cases & compatibility: Many edge cases are covered (minimum/maximum counts TC29/TC30, partial inputs TC31) and backward compatibility (TC22).
Response content: Tests assert JSON array responses and that items conform to CustomField schema (TC01 and repeated in successful scenarios).
gaps: Pagination: No test covers pagination behavior, page size, next/prev links or explicit limits/offsets even though large datasets are considered (TC11 assumes returning all fields).
Caching Behavior / HTTP Headers: No tests validate presence or correctness of caching or conditional request headers (Cache-Control, ETag, Last-Modified) or behavior on conditional GETs (304).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No explicit tests for rate limits (HTTP 429) or throttling under rapid repeated requests; concurrency and high load are tested, but not rate-limit enforcement.
Response Headers & Content-Type: There is no explicit test that validates required response headers such as Content-Type: application/json or other security headers.

Authorization scope vs role-based access control: Tests cover missing/invalid auth (401) but do not cover 403 or cases where an authenticated user lacks permission/tenant isolation to access another account’s data.
Pagination performance trade-offs: While TC11 checks large dataset and response time, it doesn’t test streaming vs memory limits or server-side pagination fallbacks.

Schema negative testing: Tests assume “matches CustomField schema” but there are no negative tests asserting schema violations are handled (malformed stored data, missing fields within returned objects).
recommendations: Add explicit pagination tests: verify behavior when results exceed a page size (e.g., limit/offset or page/token parameters if supported), correct page links, and consistent total counts.

Test caching/conditional requests: add scenarios to assert Cache-Control and ETag presence and behavior (conditional GET returning 304), and ensure immutable responses are cacheable where appropriate.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate burst traffic to validate HTTP 429 responses and backoff behavior, and document acceptable limits.

Validate response headers and Content-Type: add tests asserting Content-Type: application/json and any security headers (e.g., Strict-Transport-Security, X-Content-Type-Options) if required by policy.

Authorize/permission tests beyond 401: add tests for authenticated users without permissions (403) and tenant isolation checks to ensure one account’s custom fields cannot be accessed by another tenant or unauthorized user.

Schema robustness tests: create negative tests for malformed record cases (missing required CustomField properties) to ensure API either sanitizes or returns a clear error without leaking internal details.

Pagination performance/streaming: when returning very large numbers of fields (TC11/TC30), add tests to verify memory/CPU usage or streaming behavior and whether server-side limits are applied; validate documented limits and failure modes.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: PUT /1.0/kb/bundles/{bundleId}/resume - Resume a bundle

covered: Valid Request: Multiple success scenarios (TC01–TC04, TC18, TC24) validate correct behavior for resuming a paused bundle including required and optional headers/params.
Non-Existing Resource: TC05 verifies 404 when bundle not found.
Invalid Identifier: TC06 covers invalid UUID format with a 400 response.
Authorization: TC10 covers unauthorized access (invalid token) returning 401/403.
Required Header Validation: TC07 covers missing required X-Killbill-CreatedBy header (400).
State Validation: TC08 and TC09 cover attempts to resume bundles in invalid states (active, cancelled) with 400 responses.
Query Parameters: TC02 (requestedDate), TC03/TC13/TC19 (pluginProperty variations and limits), TC20 (requestedDate in past) check parameter handling and validation.
Optional Headers & Audit: TC04 checks reason/comment handling and audit log recording.
Concurrency: TC21 tests concurrent requests/race conditions.
Error Handling / Server Errors: TC14 models dependency failure -> 500; TC25 handles plugin service timeout behavior.
Retries/Transient Failures: TC15 validates retry behavior after transient network failure.
Security: TC16 and TC17 include SQL injection and XSS attempts to ensure safe handling.

Edge/Robustness: TC11 (extra params), TC12 (max length headers), TC26 (whitespace/case variations), TC22 (performance under load), TC23 (regression), TC25 (integration with degraded plugin) provide broad robustness coverage.
gaps: Partial Update semantics: The story indicates no request body (N/A) but there is no explicit test confirming that partial payloads (if any are sent mistakenly) are rejected or ignored — useful to assert behavior when body is present.
RequestedDate format validation: Tests cover requestedDate in the past (TC20) and valid future date (TC02) but there is no explicit test for malformed date formats (e.g., bad string) returning 400.

PluginProperty format edge cases: TC19 tests non-array value, TC16 tests injection content, and TC13 tests very large counts — but there is no test for malformed key=value pairs (e.g., missing "=" or empty key/value) and behavior is unspecified.

Deterministic Authorization codes: TC10 accepts 401 or 403; there is no explicit distinction/test that differentiates authentication vs authorization failures (e.g., expired token -> 401, insufficient permissions -> 403).

Duplicate submission idempotency/duplicate requests semantics: While concurrency (TC21) and retry (TC15) exist, there is no explicit test for duplicate identical request semantics (idempotency expectations) beyond concurrency.
Rate limiting / throttling: No tests cover rate limiting, throttling, or API quota behavior.

Response headers and content-type expectations: The acceptance mentions producing application/json for errors, but there are no explicit tests asserting response Content-Type and any caching/headers for 204 or error responses.
Observability/audit detail coverage: TC04 checks audit recording generally, but there are no tests asserting exact audit payload contents (who, when, reason, comment) or traceability fields.

Client error vs server error boundaries for plugin interactions: TC25 and TC14 cover timeouts and dependency unavailability but do not exhaustively map which plugin failures should surface as 4xx vs 5xx.
recommendations: Add a test for malformed requestedDate formats (e.g., requestedDate=not-a-date) expecting 400 to cover input validation beyond past/future semantics.
Add tests for malformed pluginProperty entries (missing "=" or empty key/value) to validate parameter parsing and error messages.
Add an idempotency/duplicate-request test to assert expected behavior when identical resume requests are re-sent (beyond concurrency/retry scenarios).

Split authorization tests into distinct scenarios for authentication (expired/invalid token -> 401) and authorization (valid token but insufficient permissions -> 403) to be explicit and deterministic.

Add assertions for response headers and content-type for both success (204) and error responses (error Content-Type application/json, relevant error fields) to meet the "Produces: application/json" note.
Add a test to confirm behavior when a request includes an unexpected request body (since payload is N/A in the spec) — ensure the server rejects or ignores it consistently.
Add rate-limiting/throttling tests if the API is subject to quotas (simulate many rapid requests and assert 429 or acceptable behavior).
Expand audit/log assertions to validate the exact recorded fields for reason/comment/createdBy and timestamps where required, to improve observability coverage.
Clarify and add tests mapping plugin/service failure types to expected HTTP codes (e.g., plugin validation -> 4xx vs plugin outage -> 5xx) to remove ambiguity.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: POST /1.0/kb/accounts/payments - Trigger a payment using the account external key

covered: Valid Payload: Multiple scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC06, TC22, TC23) validate successful creation with required, optional, minimal and boundary payloads.
Invalid/Malformed Payload: TC09 covers malformed JSON and TC11 covers invalid paymentMethodId -> appropriate 4xx responses.
Required Parameters & Headers Validation: TC01/TC08/TC10 validate presence/absence of required query parameter externalKey and required header X-Killbill-CreatedBy.
Optional Parameters: TC02, TC04, TC05, TC25 cover optional query parameters controlPluginName, pluginProperty, paymentMethodId and plugin property handling.

Gateway/plugin error handling: TC12 (402 declined), TC13 (422 aborted by control plugin), TC14 (502 submission failure), TC15 (503 unknown status), TC16 (504 timeout) cover the specified error response matrix.
Not Found / Empty account: TC07 and TC20 cover account-not-found cases (404) including empty DB.
Authorization: TC17 covers unauthorized access (401).
Security: TC18 tests malicious payload handling (sanitization / non-execution + logging requirement).
Boundary / Large payload tests: TC21 covers large payload behaviour and TC22 minimal values.
Integration & Dependency failure: TC24 covers dependent service (gateway) down scenarios.
Performance: TC27–TC29 include response-time and resource-utilization/performance expectations.
Regression & Backwards compatibility: TC25 and TC26 address regressions and backward compatibility.
Location header & Response schema: Successful scenarios assert 201 and Location header plus Payment object in body (covered in success cases).
gaps: Duplicate Submission / Idempotency: No scenario tests duplicate submissions (replay of same request) or idempotency behavior / deduplication.
Server Error (500) / Internal Failures: No explicit scenario simulates server-side failures like DB errors resulting in 500 responses (server error handling).

POST Specific: Content-Type enforcement and strict schema validation edge-cases (e.g., wrong data types for amount, currency format validation) are only partially covered; there are no explicit tests for numeric range validation or precise schema field validation beyond malformed JSON.

Strictness for unsupported params: TC19 allows both 201 or 400 depending on strictness, but there is no explicit assertion of how unknown query/body parameters are handled (reject vs ignore) in a deterministic way.

Duplicate/Concurrent Submissions Race Conditions: There are no concurrency tests for duplicate requests causing double-charges (functional concurrency/idempotency testing distinct from performance load).
Rate Limiting & Throttling: No tests cover API rate limiting behavior or throttling (standard guideline missing).
Caching Behavior: Not applicable in POST normally, but there are no tests for any cache-related headers or behavior (e.g., ensure no unintended caching).

Pagination (GET guideline): The standard GET guideline items (pagination, caching headers, ETag) are not relevant for this POST story and are not covered — if the API exposes GET resources for payments, tests are missing.
Content negotiation / Accept header: Tests don’t assert Content-Type and Accept handling (application/json required responses).

Detailed response body validation: While Payment object presence is asserted, there are no explicit assertions for all critical fields (transaction id, amounts, currency, transaction type, status transitions) or schema negative tests for partial/missing response fields.
recommendations: Add duplicate submission/idempotency scenarios: test re-submitting the same PaymentTransaction (same client-generated idempotency key if supported) and assert no double-charge or consistent behavior (409/200/201 as per API design).
Add server-side failure simulations: introduce tests that simulate DB or internal service errors resulting in 500 and assert graceful error handling and logging.

Expand validation tests: include targeted field-level validation tests (invalid amount types, out-of-range amounts, invalid currency codes, invalid transactionType values) with expected 4xx responses and clear error messages.
Make unsupported-parameter behavior deterministic: add explicit tests asserting whether unknown query/body params are ignored or rejected and document expected behavior.
Add concurrency/idempotency race tests: simulate concurrent identical requests and verify single payment creation or safe handling to prevent double charges.
Add rate-limiting tests: hammer the endpoint to validate throttling behavior and proper 429 responses (if applicable).
Assert Content-Type/Accept headers: add tests that omit or set incorrect Content-Type/Accept headers and assert 415/406/400 responses as appropriate.
Enhance response body assertions: verify required Payment fields (ids, amounts, currency, status, transaction list) and validate Location header format and link correctness.
If GET endpoints exist for payments, add separate feature tests covering GET-specific guidelines (pagination, caching headers, ETag, empty responses).
Add explicit caching/no-cache assertions for POST responses to ensure clients won’t cache POST responses inadvertently (e.g., check Cache-Control headers).

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/emails/{email} - Delete email from account

covered: Valid Deletion: Successful deletion scenarios present (TC01, TC02, TC12, TC13, TC17, TC18).
Non-Existent Resource: Missing account and missing email scenarios present (TC03, TC04, TC09).
Input Validation: Invalid accountId and invalid email format scenarios (TC05, TC06) plus XSS/injection case (TC16).
Required Header Validation: Missing required header checked (TC07).
Authorization: Unauthorized token scenario covered (TC10).
Concurrency: Concurrent deletion race condition covered (TC15).
Transient/Recovery and Dependency Failures: Transient network retry and downstream service unavailable scenarios covered (TC19, TC11).
Performance: A basic response-time SLA check included (TC14).
Edge cases: Very long and minimal-length email addresses covered (TC12, TC13).
Backward compatibility/regression: Regression and legacy client scenarios included (TC17, TC18).
gaps: Soft Delete Semantics: No tests verify whether deletion is soft (marked deleted) versus hard delete (permanent removal) or that related audit/logging/metadata are updated.

Idempotency Semantics: While concurrency is tested, there is no explicit test asserting idempotency guarantees beyond expected 204 then 404 responses (e.g., repeated identical DELETE beyond concurrent window).
Authorization Scopes/Roles: Only invalid-token (401) is tested; there are no tests for forbidden access (403) where a valid token lacks sufficient permissions/roles.
Header Validation Variants: No tests for invalid or malformed X-Killbill-CreatedBy values (too long, empty string) or for optional headers causing validation issues.

Detailed Error Codes/Body Structure: Tests assert presence of error messages but do not validate standardized error payload structure (fields, codes) or exact HTTP response bodies for all error cases.
Rate Limiting and Throttling: No tests covering rate limiting or behavior under heavy request bursts.
Caching Behavior: No tests for caching-related headers or behavior (ETag, Cache-Control) — likely irrelevant for DELETE but still useful for clients to observe cache invalidation.
Logging/Audit Trail: No checks that the deletion is recorded in audit logs or that X-Killbill-CreatedBy/Reason/Comment are persisted.
Boundary/value limits for accountId length/format variations beyond simple invalid format: no tests for extremely long accountId or unicode characters.
Content Negotiation / Accept Headers: No tests for Accept/Content-Type headers or behavior when client asks for different media types.
recommendations: Add tests to assert soft-delete vs hard-delete semantics and check that deleted email is not retrievable via GET and that audit metadata (deletedBy, deletedReason, deletedDate) is recorded when applicable.
Add explicit idempotency tests: issue the same DELETE multiple times serially and assert consistent responses and side effects (first 204, subsequent 404 or idempotent 204 depending on API contract).
Add role/permission tests to cover 403 Forbidden scenarios where the token is valid but lacks deletion permissions.
Expand header validation tests: include malformed/empty X-Killbill-CreatedBy, excessively long header values, and verify optional headers are recorded but not required.
Standardize error-response validation: validate error JSON schema (fields like code, message, type) and exact status/body combinations for all error scenarios.
Introduce rate-limiting / throttling tests (burst of DELETEs) to observe 429 or other protective behaviors.
If applicable, add caching-related checks to ensure server instructs caches correctly or invalidates caches after deletion (verify absence/presence of Cache-Control / ETag behavior where relevant).
Add tests to verify audit/log persistence: ensure X-Killbill-CreatedBy/X-Killbill-Reason/X-Killbill-Comment values appear in audit logs or resource history.
Add boundary tests for accountId (very long, unicode, edge-case characters) and email local-part/domain edge cases beyond length (unicode, sub-addressing, plus-addressing).
Add content-negotiation tests (Accept header variations) to ensure consistent error/empty responses and response media types.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/admin/healthcheck - Put the host out of rotation

covered: Valid Deletion: TC01 and related regression TC12 validate a successful DELETE and that the host is marked out of rotation (expected 204).
Authentication: TC02 and TC03 cover missing and invalid authentication cases (401 scenarios).
Idempotency / Non-existent resource: TC04 (host already out of rotation) and TC14 (no hosts in rotation) cover attempts to delete when there is nothing to act on (409 responses).
Service and system errors: TC05 (service down -> 503) and TC06 (internal error -> 500) cover error handling during operation.
Method validation: TC07 checks invalid HTTP method handling (405).
Request validation: TC09 checks behavior for an unexpected/non-empty or malicious request body (400).
Extra/ignored query params: TC08 validates behavior when extra parameters are provided (still returns 204 and proceeds).
Concurrency and performance: TC10 and TC11 provide performance expectations and concurrent request behavior (first wins, subsequent 409/204).
Security header injection: TC13 covers malicious header content and expects defensive handling (400/401).
gaps: Content-Type / Response format: The Jira story specifies the API "Produces: application/json", yet most success scenarios assert an empty body for 204 and there is no test asserting response Content-Type or response body for error responses consistently. There is no explicit check that error responses are application/json with a structured error payload.

Idempotency semantics specifics: While TC04/TC11 touch idempotency/concurrent behavior, there is no explicit test to assert strict idempotency semantics (e.g., repeated identical DELETE calls by same client should consistently return the same status after initial call).
Soft-delete vs permanent: No tests verify whether the host is soft-deleted (flag set) versus permanently removed, or whether the change is reversible (e.g., a subsequent PUT/POST to bring host back).

Authorization scope / roles / 403 handling: Tests cover unauthenticated (401) and invalid token (401) but do not cover authenticated users without proper privileges (403) or role-based access control.
Response headers and caching: No tests assert headers (e.g., Cache-Control, ETag) or other operational headers that could be important for admin APIs.
Audit / logging / side effects: No tests validate audit logs, metrics, or that downstream systems (load balancers / health monitors) observe the host as out of rotation.
Non-HTTP edge cases: No tests for malformed URLs, path casing, or variations in base URL.
recommendations: Add assertions for response Content-Type and structured error payloads (application/json) for both success and error cases — ensure 204 responses still produce correct headers and error responses conform to JSON schema.
Add tests to explicitly verify idempotency: repeated DELETEs from same client produce deterministic results and documented status codes.
Add a test to verify soft-delete semantics (if applicable): check the host record flag, and whether it can be re-enabled, or whether deletion is reversible.
Add authorization role tests to cover 403 Forbidden where a valid token lacks admin privileges.
Add tests that assert relevant response headers (Cache-Control, ETag, Retry-After for 503 if applicable) and any security headers required by policy.

Add integration tests that verify side-effects: e.g., query the system / health status endpoint or downstream load-balancer simulation to confirm the host is observed out of rotation; check audit logs/metrics for the admin action.

Extend performance tests to include sustained load, rate-limiting and throttling behavior beyond the current single/short concurrency scenarios (verify graceful degradation and appropriate 429 or backoff behavior if present).

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/catalog/availableBasePlans - Retrieve available base plans

covered: Valid Request: Multiple scenarios (TC01, TC02) validate successful retrieval with and without accountId and assert 200 + JSON body.
Empty Response: TC03 and TC14 explicitly cover empty-catalog responses and confirm 200 + empty array.
Query Parameters: TC02, TC04, TC05, TC08 cover valid accountId, non-existent accountId, invalid-format accountId, and extra/unsupported params.
Authorization: TC06 verifies unauthorized access returns 401 and an error message.
Error Handling: TC07, TC17 cover service unavailability and timeout cases (503 and 504 expectations).
Security: TC12 and TC13 cover SQL injection and XSS attempts on accountId parameter.
Performance / Load: TC09, TC10, TC11 exercise response time and large-payload behavior under normal, concurrent, and maximal-data scenarios.
Integration / Partial Data: TC16 addresses degraded dependent service behavior and partial-content expectations.
Response Structure / Accessibility: TC01/TC02/TC18 require JSON response and PlanDetail fields (structure and machine-readable).
gaps: Pagination: No scenarios test pagination, offsets, limits, or behavior when the dataset is large and pagination is expected/required.
Caching Behavior: No tests validate caching headers (ETag, Last-Modified, Cache-Control) or conditional GETs (If-None-Match / 304 handling).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests for API rate limits, burst traffic handling, or 429 responses.
Detailed Authorization Variants: Only 401 unauthorized is covered; missing tests for forbidden access (403) or tenant-scoped access control differences.

Schema Validation / Field-level Limits: Tests assert presence of PlanDetail objects but do not validate required field formats, types, ranges, or optional vs required fields in detail (e.g., price formats, UUID formats inside objects).

Error Code Coverage: General 5xx server error (500) or malformed responses are not explicitly tested beyond service-down (503); also distinction between 400 vs 422 validation responses is assumed but not exhaustively validated for different invalid inputs.
Pagination-related performance: While large payload tests exist (TC11), they do not test server behavior when pagination should be used (streaming, truncated results, next/prev links).
Caching + Concurrent Mutations: No tests for stale data scenarios (cache invalidation) or concurrent updates affecting the returned catalog during reads.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: include scenarios that request page/limit params (if supported) or assert behavior when dataset exceeds a single response (e.g., limit=50, offset=50), and verify next/prev links or headers.
Add caching tests: verify presence and correctness of Cache-Control, ETag/Last-Modified headers; include conditional GETs using If-None-Match to expect 304 when appropriate.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate burst requests to confirm 429 responses and retry-after headers, and assert graceful handling under throttling.
Expand authorization tests: include tenant-scoped access checks, 403 forbidden scenarios, and role-based access tests where applicable.
Add detailed schema validation tests: assert required PlanDetail fields, types, formats (prices, UUIDs, enums), min/max constraints, and behavior on missing fields.
Add broader error-code coverage: include tests for 500 internal server error, malformed responses, and ensure errors do not leak sensitive data.
Test cache-staleness and concurrent mutations: simulate catalog update during reads to ensure API’s consistency guarantees or documented eventual-consistency behavior.
Clarify and parametrize validation behavior (400 vs 422): add tests that assert the precise status code and error payload for specific invalid inputs per API contract.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/bundles/{bundleId}/customFields - Remove custom fields from bundle

covered: Valid Deletion: Multiple scenarios (TC01–TC05, TC18) verify successful deletion semantics including full, partial, single and multiple customField removals and correct 204 responses.
Query Parameters: Good coverage for query parameter use-cases — valid single, multiple, empty, invalid formats, extra/unsupported parameters (TC02, TC03, TC09, TC11, TC19).

Headers / Validation: Required header X-Killbill-CreatedBy presence and absence are tested (TC04, TC08, TC18). Optional headers X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment are tested including boundary lengths (TC04, TC20, TC21).

Error scenarios: Invalid bundleId format and truncated UUID handled (TC06, TC22), non-existent bundle and empty DB cases produce 404 (TC07, TC23), invalid/expired auth token produces 401 (TC13), and malformed customField UUID produces 400 (TC09).
Idempotency / Non-present items: Deleting a custom field not present returns 204 and leaves others intact (TC10).
Concurrency and Race Conditions: Concurrent delete requests and regression tests ensuring changes do not affect other bundles are covered (TC16, TC17).
Performance and scale: Large-volume performance test for deleting many custom fields included (TC15).
Security / Input Safety: Injection/malicious payload in header is considered (TC14).
Integration / Resilience: Service unavailable and dependent service degradation/timeout scenarios are included (TC12, TC24).
Post-deletion verification: Many scenarios include a subsequent GET to verify state and data consistency (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC05, TC25).
gaps: Soft Delete Semantics: No explicit test to verify whether deletions are soft (flagging) vs hard (physically removed) and retrieval from audit/history endpoints. The story doesn’t state soft-delete behavior, but tests don’t assert persistence/audit records.

Authorization/Permissions Granularity: Tests cover authentication failure (401) and missing required header (400) but do not cover authorization/permission levels (e.g., 403 Forbidden for authenticated but unauthorized users or role-based access control).
Rate Limiting and Throttling: No tests exercising rate limits or behavior under burst traffic apart from the performance single-request scenario.
Caching Behavior for GET verification: Tests use GET to verify state but do not assert caching headers (ETag/Cache-Control) or stale cache handling after deletion.

Pagination / Large-list GET behaviors: No tests for pagination when listing custom fields (e.g., if GET custom fields supports pagination for very large numbers), nor for DELETE when combined with paginated lists.

Duplicate/Repeated Requests Semantics: While idempotency is partially covered by TC10 and TC16, there is no explicit test for duplicate simultaneous requests deleting the same set of fields in quick succession beyond two concurrent requests, nor verification of retry semantics on network failures.

Error content validation: Tests assert status codes and presence of an error message but do not validate standardized error payload structure/fields (error codes, errorType, timestamps) or localization.
recommendations: Add tests for soft-delete vs hard-delete behavior and audit/history retrieval to assert whether records remain in audit tables or are purged.
Introduce authorization tests for role/permission scenarios producing 403 Forbidden to ensure only permitted principals can delete custom fields.
Add rate-limiting/throttling tests (burst requests) to validate 429 responses or throttling behavior and graceful degradation.
Add caching-related tests verifying ETag/Cache-Control headers on GETs used for post-deletion verification and ensure clients receive fresh data after deletion (cache invalidation).
Add pagination tests for GET custom fields when listing large numbers (and verify DELETE semantics when many items span pages), or confirm API does not paginate and document accordingly.
Add structured error payload assertions to ensure error responses follow the expected schema and contain helpful diagnostic fields.
Expand duplicate/retry semantics tests: e.g., multiple rapid repeated DELETEs and client retries after network timeouts to confirm idempotency and observe no negative side effects.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/credits/{creditId} - Retrieve a credit by id

covered: Valid Request: TC01 and TC02 verify successful retrieval for CREDIT_ADJ and CBA_ADJ and validate response body/type/ID.
Empty Response: TC03 and TC18 cover scenarios where no matching credits exist and expect 404.
Query Parameters: TC08 tests that unexpected query parameters are ignored and do not affect result.
Authorization: TC06 and TC07 validate missing and invalid/expired authentication tokens (401).
Input Validation: TC05, TC12, TC13, TC16, TC17 validate invalid UUID formats, injection attempts, truncated/whitespace-padded IDs and expect 400 responses.
Non-existent Resource: TC04 and TC14 check non-existent or unusual-but-valid-looking IDs return 404.
Type Restriction: TC11 verifies that InvoiceItems of other types are not returned (404).
Error Handling / Service Unavailable: TC10 checks behavior when dependent DB is down (503).
Performance & Concurrency: TC09 and TC19 cover acceptable response times under load and concurrent requests.
Regression / Backward Compatibility: TC15 and TC20 cover known-bug regression and API backward compatibility checks.
Security: TC12 and TC13 include SQLi and XSS style checks and assert the system is not compromised.
gaps: Pagination: No tests cover pagination behavior or large-result navigations (page size, offsets, next/prev links) — relevant if endpoint could return lists in other designs or if future changes add listing behavior.
Caching Behavior: No scenarios verify caching headers (ETag, Last-Modified, Cache-Control) or conditional GETs (If-None-Match / 304 semantics).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: While concurrency/performance is tested, there are no tests validating rate-limiting responses (e.g., 429) or behavior when the client exceeds request quotas.
Header Validation: No explicit tests for required/optional headers (Accept, Accept-Version) or content-negotiation edge cases.

Content Schema Validation: While response body is asserted as a valid InvoiceItem, there are no negative tests that verify specific required fields presence/format (e.g., amount, currency, invoiceId) or behavior when some fields are missing/corrupt.
Authorization Scopes / Permissions: Tests cover authentication but do not cover authorization/permission variations (403) — e.g., authenticated user lacking permission to view a particular credit.
Logging/Audit: No tests to ensure sensitive operations are logged/audited (if required by non-functional requirements).
Internationalization / Encoding: No tests for IDs with unusual encodings or header encodings; not likely required for UUID but worth noting.
recommendations: Add pagination tests if the API or related endpoints support returning collections — verify page size, offsets, and navigation links.
Add caching tests: verify presence and correctness of ETag and Cache-Control headers, and test conditional GET behavior (If-None-Match -> 304).
Include rate-limiting tests that simulate client exceeding allowed request rates and assert correct 429 or retry-after behavior.
Add header and content-negotiation tests (e.g., Accept: application/json vs. other types) and validate appropriate status codes or content-type handling.
Expand schema validation tests to assert required InvoiceItem fields and types (amount, currency, invoiceId, createdDate), and add negative tests where fields are missing or malformed.
Add authorization scope tests to differentiate between authenticated-but-unauthorized (403) and unauthenticated (401) scenarios, if the system enforces per-resource permissions.
Consider adding tests that validate logging/audit behavior and ensure no sensitive data is leaked in error messages.
If relevant, include tests for unusual encodings and ensure the service safely handles unexpected characters in path parameters.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: POST /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/block - Block an account

covered: Valid Payload: Multiple successful POST scenarios (TC01–TC05, TC16–TC17, TC20) verify resource creation and 201 responses.
Invalid Payload: Malformed JSON, missing body, and malformed fields are tested (TC09, TC10, TC14).
Path Parameter Validation: Invalid accountId format and SQL injection-like input are tested (TC07, TC13).
Authorization: Unauthorized access test exists (TC11) to verify authentication failure handling.
Required Headers Validation: Missing required header X-Killbill-CreatedBy is tested (TC08).
Query Parameters: requestedDate and pluginProperty presence/absence/empty-array behaviour are covered (TC02–TC05, TC15).
Large Payloads: Large payload near size limit is covered (TC20).
Performance / Concurrency: High concurrency and sustained-load scenarios are present (TC25, TC26).
Server Error Handling (partial): Database unavailable scenario is covered (TC12) and plugin-unavailable handled (TC22).
Duplicate Handling / Regression: A regression test ensures no duplicate BlockingState entries (TC23).
Integration with plugins: Plugin-success and plugin-unavailable scenarios are present (TC21, TC22).
Edge cases: Max/min field lengths and empty pluginProperty are covered (TC15, TC16, TC17).
Response semantics: Tests assert 201 and that response body contains BlockingState objects (TC01–TC05, etc.).
gaps: Server Error 500: No explicit test for generic 500 Internal Server Error (e.g., unexpected exception path) — only 503 is covered.

Duplicate Submission / Idempotency: There is a regression test preventing duplicate entries (TC23) but no explicit test for repeated identical POST requests to verify duplicate-submission handling / idempotency behavior.
Validation coverage depth: Field-level validation cases (invalid data types, out-of-range values inside BlockingState, missing required fields within the JSON schema) are not exhaustively covered.
Content-Type and Header Variations: There is no explicit test for incorrect Content-Type (e.g., missing or wrong Content-Type) or other header edge-cases besides X-Killbill-CreatedBy.
Response Schema Validation: Tests assert presence of BlockingState(s) but do not validate full response schema, status of individual fields, or standard error payload structure consistently.
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests for rate limiting or API throttling behavior.

Pagination / GET-related concerns: Although not directly applicable to this POST, the standard guideline references pagination for endpoints that return lists — no tests validate server behavior when large arrays are returned beyond usual size limits aside from TC20.
Caching Headers: No tests validate caching-related headers (ETag, Cache-Control) — while less relevant for POST, headers or response caching behavior for returned resources is not asserted.

Concurrency race conditions on same resource: High concurrency (TC25) uses different accounts; no test covers race conditions when multiple requests attempt to block the same account simultaneously (possible duplicate/conflict conditions).

Error code completeness: The story requires 400 for invalid accountId or malformed body and 404 for not found — those are present; however tests do not assert error payload contents/structure consistently or varied client error cases (e.g., invalid pluginProperty types leading to 400).
recommendations: Add a test that simulates an unexpected server error path returning 500 to ensure standard server-error handling and error payload format.

Add explicit duplicate-submission tests: send the same POST twice (or concurrently) to the same account and verify idempotency or appropriate duplicate handling (e.g., second request returns 409 or is a no-op).

Expand field-level validation tests: include cases with invalid data types for BlockingState fields, missing required fields inside the JSON body, and out-of-range values to ensure validation rules are enforced and mapped to 400 responses with clear error messages.
Add Content-Type and header-variation tests: missing/wrong Content-Type, extra/malformed headers, and header value boundary tests.

Validate response schema and error schema strictly: assert specific fields and their types in the created BlockingState objects and standardize checks for error response structure and messages for 4xx/5xx.
Add rate-limiting/throttling tests: simulate burst traffic from same client and verify the API responds with 429 or other configured throttling behavior when limits are exceeded.

Add concurrency tests targeting the same account: simulate multiple simultaneous requests to block the same account to uncover race conditions and ensure duplicate creation does not occur or is handled deterministically.
Add tests that check pluginProperty validation errors (wrong types) and plugin failure modes beyond availability (e.g., plugin returns error payload vs. timeout).
Add a test for incorrect/missing authentication scopes or permissions (403) if the API differentiates authn vs authz, to fully cover authorization guidelines.

Document and add tests (if applicable) for any caching or header behaviors returned by POST responses (for clients that may rely on headers), or explicitly assert that caching headers are absent for POST responses.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/auditLogsWithHistory - Retrieve account audit logs with history by account id

covered: Valid Request: Successful retrieval for a valid accountId is covered (TC01).
Empty Response: No-audit-log case is covered (TC02).
Error Handling (Non-existent Resource): 404 when account not found is covered (TC03).
Input Validation (accountId format): invalid/partial/whitespace/account length/case-sensitivity cases covered (TC04, TC14, TC15, TC16, TC17).
Authorization: missing and expired/invalid token scenarios covered (TC05, TC06).
Server Errors: internal server error/database unavailable scenario covered (TC07).
Unsupported Parameters: a test that unsupported query parameters are ignored is present (TC08).
Large Dataset / Performance: large history and response-time expectations are included (TC09).
Concurrency/Load: concurrent requests and average response time expectations are included (TC11).
Security: SQL injection attempt on path param is included (TC10).
Regression/Schema: mandatory fields / previously fixed bug validation is included (TC12).
Dependency Degradation: degraded dependency and fallback behaviors are included (TC13).
gaps: Pagination: No scenario exercises pagination (limit/offset or page tokens) or verifies behavior when results exceed any per-response limit.

Query Parameters: Only “unsupported params ignored” is present — there is no coverage of valid optional query parameters, combinatorial query param validation, or invalid query param values (e.g., date ranges, filters, sort).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: Although TC11 exercises concurrent requests for performance, there is no explicit test of rate limiting responses (e.g., 429 Too Many Requests) or backoff behavior.
Caching Behavior: No tests verify caching headers (ETag, Last-Modified, Cache-Control) or conditional GET behavior (If-None-Match, If-Modified-Since).

Authorization Granularity: Tests cover authentication failures (401) but not authorization/permission scenarios (403) — e.g., authenticated user without permission to view another account’s audit logs.
Response Schema Edge Cases: While mandatory fields are checked, there is no negative test for malformed AuditLog entries, unexpected field types, or extra fields in returned objects.
Internationalization / Encoding: No tests for unusual characters in account-related fields or audit log content (UTF-8 / control characters).
Rate/Load Stability: TC11 asserts performance SLA but does not verify behavior under sustained high load over time (endurance) or burst patterns.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: simulate accounts with audit logs that exceed a single response page; verify page size, next/prev links or tokens, correct total counts, and behavior at page boundaries.

Add query-parameter coverage: include tests for any supported filters (date ranges, event types, sort orders), invalid parameter values, and combinatorial combinations to ensure validation and correct filtering/sorting.
Add explicit rate-limiting tests: verify the system returns 429 and appropriate Retry-After headers when client exceeds allowed request rate; test client/backoff behavior.
Add caching and conditional GET tests: verify ETag/Last-Modified presence, that If-None-Match/If-Modified-Since produce 304 when appropriate, and Cache-Control headers are correct.
Add authorization/permission tests: include scenarios where an authenticated user lacks permission to view a target account’s audit logs and expect 403 Forbidden.
Add schema robustness tests: include cases where backend returns malformed or unexpected AuditLog objects to confirm the API handles them gracefully (validation errors or safe defaults).
Add endurance and burst load tests: run sustained load and burst scenarios to detect resource leaks or instability over time.
Add internationalization/encoding tests: include audit log entries and account metadata with unicode, long strings, and control characters to ensure safe serialization and transport.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/customFields - Retrieve account custom fields

covered: Valid Request: Multiple scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC16) verify successful retrieval with valid accountId and audit parameter combinations.
Empty Response: TC04 and TC05 cover accounts with no custom fields and non-existent accounts returning an empty array (HTTP 200) as per the story.
Query Parameters: audit parameter is tested for valid values (NONE/DEFAULT, FULL, MINIMAL) and invalid values (TC07). Also TC10 covers unsupported extra query parameters being ignored.
Authorization: TC08 and TC09 cover missing and invalid authentication tokens (HTTP 401).
Input validation / Security: TC06, TC13, TC14 cover invalid accountId format and injection/XSS attempts leading to HTTP 400.
Error handling & resilience: TC11, TC15, TC18 cover service unavailable, network timeout, and dependent service failures with appropriate error status expectations.
Performance / Scale: TC12 validates behavior and a performance SLA for a very large number of custom fields.
Concurrency: TC17 covers concurrent requests for the same accountId to ensure consistency.
Regression / Schema compatibility: TC19 and TC16 address backward compatibility and a specific regression around audit handling.
Response quality: TC20 ensures the response is well-formed JSON and parsable.
gaps: Pagination: No tests for pagination or limit/offset parameters. The guidelines explicitly call out pagination for large datasets; TC12 stresses large volume but does not verify pagination behavior or partial responses.
Caching Behavior: No scenarios check caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified) or conditional GET behavior (304 Not Modified).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: There are concurrency tests (TC17) but no tests for rate limiting, throttling, or HTTP 429 behavior under high request rates.
Authorization: While 401 (authentication) is covered, there are no tests for authorization/permissions (e.g., 403 Forbidden) or role-based access control if applicable.

Pagination-related performance and memory: TC12 asserts overall response time but does not test memory usage, streaming responses, or server behavior when returning extremely large payloads in paginated vs non-paginated modes.
Content Negotiation / Headers: No tests verify Content-Type consistency beyond JSON or verify Accept header handling.
ETag/Conditional Requests and Cache Invalidation: No tests for conditional requests (If-None-Match / If-Modified-Since) or cache invalidation after updates to custom fields.

Schema validation depth: While success cases expect CustomField objects, there are no explicit tests validating the full CustomField schema (required/optional fields, types, nested objects) beyond general assertions.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: introduce scenarios that request paginated results (limit, offset or page parameters), validate page sizes, next/prev links if applicable, and behavior when page > max pages. Include test for very large dataset split across pages to ensure consistent ordering and completeness.

Test caching and conditional requests: add scenarios that assert ETag and Cache-Control headers, perform conditional GETs with If-None-Match / If-Modified-Since to verify 304 responses, and check cache invalidation after a resource change.
Add rate limiting / throttling tests: simulate high request rates to validate 429 responses or configured throttling behavior and verify retry-after headers.
Extend authorization coverage: add tests for 403 Forbidden where an authenticated user lacks permission, if the API has RBAC or account-scoped access rules.
Schema validation tests: add assertions that each CustomField object matches the expected schema (field names, types, presence/absence depending on audit level).
Content negotiation and headers: add tests for Accept and Content-Type header handling, and validate consistent response Content-Type and character encoding.
Pagination + performance: for large datasets, include tests that assert acceptable memory/streaming behavior and that server honors pagination to avoid returning massive single responses.
Conditional error cases: test combinations of invalid parameters with different auth states (e.g., invalid audit + missing auth) to ensure predictable error precedence and consistent status codes.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/invoicePayments/{paymentId}/tags - Remove tags from payment

covered: Valid Deletion: Multiple success scenarios (TC01-TC05, TC10, TC15) validate deleting all/specific/multiple tags and behavior when none present.
Input validation: Scenarios for invalid paymentId format (TC06) and invalid tagDef format / injection (TC09, TC13) are present.
Non-Existent Resource: Non-existent paymentId case is covered (TC07).
Required headers: Missing required header is covered (TC08) and optional headers (Reason/Comment) are covered (TC04).
Authorization: Unauthorized access is tested (TC11).
Concurrency: Concurrent deletion scenario is included (TC16).
Error handling & resilience: Service unavailable, timeout and system error cases covered (TC12, TC22).
Operational/non-functional: Performance/load (TC17) and large input (TC15) are included.
Audit & consistency: Audit logging, data consistency and regression checks are included (TC20, TC21, TC18).
Extra/unknown params: Unexpected query parameter handling is covered (TC14).
gaps: Pagination: No tests cover pagination or related behavior — while not typical for DELETE, the standard guidelines mention pagination for list endpoints and large dataset interactions which could be relevant for systems that batch-delete or validate large tag lists.
Caching Behavior: No scenarios verify caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control) or effects of caches on DELETE semantics.
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests exercise API rate limits (bursts/429 responses) or throttling behavior under repeated requests.

Soft Delete Semantics: No explicit test verifies whether deletion is soft (marked deleted) vs hard delete and how that impacts subsequent GETs beyond basic consistency (TC21 checks GET but not deleted-flag visibility).
Authentication/Authorization granularity: There is an unauthorized test, but no tests for insufficient privileges (403) or role-based access control variations.
Request/Response contract details: No tests assert response headers (Content-Type for 204 should be empty) or ensure the API produces the declared application/json in error responses consistently.

Edge-case collection formatting: While multiple tagDef parameters are tested, there is no explicit test for malformed collection formats (e.g., tagDef repeated vs comma-separated) beyond invalid UUID format.
recommendations: Add rate limiting tests to validate behavior under request bursts and proper 429 handling.
Add caching-related tests: verify that DELETE invalidates caches and check headers like ETag/Cache-Control where applicable.
Add explicit tests for soft-delete semantics: verify whether tags are marked deleted, visible via admin/audit endpoints, and how soft delete affects GET results over time.
Include RBAC/403 tests to cover cases where an authenticated user exists but lacks permission to remove tags.
Add tests to assert response headers and consistent error response Content-Type and structure for both 4xx and 5xx responses.
Add tests for collection-format edge cases (comma-separated tagDef values, repeated params, empty tagDef list) to ensure robust parsing.

If the service supports batch operations that could be paginated or streamed, add pagination/large-set tests or at least stress tests that validate behavior when the server must process very large tag lists.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/block - Retrieve blocking states for account

covered: Valid Request: Multiple scenarios cover successful retrieval with no filters and with combinations of query parameters (TC01-TC07, TC22, TC20).
Empty Response: Scenarios cover accounts with no blocking states and non-existent accounts returning empty arrays (TC08, TC09, TC23).

Query Parameters: Extensive tests for valid and invalid query parameter values (blockingStateTypes, blockingStateSvcs, audit) including multiple values and unsupported parameters (TC02-TC04, TC11, TC12, TC13, TC21).
Authorization: Unauthorized access is covered (missing and invalid tokens) (TC14, TC15).
Error Handling: Input validation errors for invalid accountId and invalid parameter values are covered (TC10, TC11, TC12).
Service/Dependency Failures: Service unavailable and dependent service failures are covered (TC16, TC25).
Large Data / Performance Considerations: Large-volume retrieval and timeout handling are addressed (TC17, TC19), as well as degraded performance scenarios (TC24).
Security Input Validation: Injection attack in parameters is tested (TC18).
Concurrency / Load: Concurrent request handling and resource utilization are covered (TC27).
Regression / Compatibility: Regression test for multi-value filters and backward compatibility for legacy clients are present (TC21, TC20).
Data Consistency / Integration: Tests for data consistency across integrated systems are present (TC26).
gaps: Pagination: No tests exercise pagination, limits, offsets, or link headers for large result sets (guideline expects pagination coverage).
Caching Behavior: No tests check cache-related headers (ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified) or conditional GET behavior.
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests verify API behaviour under rapid repeated requests and rate-limit responses (429) or proper Retry-After behavior.
Content-Type and Response Headers: Tests do not assert Content-Type (application/json) or other response headers required by the API contract.

HTTP 500 / Unexpected Server Errors: There are service-unavailable tests, but no explicit tests validating 500 Internal Server Error handling and well-formed error responses for unexpected server-side failures.
Authorization scope/403: Tests cover 401 cases but not 403 Forbidden scenarios (e.g., authenticated but unauthorized client or insufficient permissions).
Pagination + Performance: While large-volume retrieval is present, there is no test combining pagination with performance limits to verify correct partial retrieval and response times when paginated.

Schema edge-cases: While "required fields as per schema" is asserted in TC01, there are no explicit negative tests for partially malformed BlockingState objects in responses (e.g., missing required fields produced by upstream systems).
Rate-limited concurrent behavior: Concurrency is tested for correctness, but not combined with rate-limit exhaustion and graceful degradation.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: create scenarios for page size, offset/limit, boundary conditions (zero, max allowed), and verify link headers or paging metadata if applicable.
Add caching tests: verify ETag and Cache-Control headers are present and valid; test conditional GETs (If-None-Match / If-Modified-Since) to ensure 304 responses when appropriate.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate burst requests to verify 429 responses, Retry-After semantics, and graceful degradation under throttling.

Assert response headers and content type: add checks for Content-Type: application/json and any required custom headers (e.g., X-Request-Id), and validate consistent error response structure for 4xx/5xx.
Cover 500 Internal Server Error: add tests to simulate unexpected server-side failures (e.g., DB exception) and verify a consistent 500 response and no leakage of sensitive info.
Add 403 Forbidden scenarios: cover cases where authentication is valid but the caller lacks permission to view the account blocking states.
Improve schema negative tests: include cases where upstream/integrated systems return malformed BlockingState entries and ensure API either sanitizes or returns a clear error.
Combine pagination and performance tests: validate response sizes, times and resource usage when retrieving paginated large datasets.
Rate-limit + concurrency: include tests exercising concurrency until rate limits are hit to validate correct interaction between load and throttling.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/emails/{accountEmailId}/auditLogsWithHistory - Retrieve account email audit logs with history by id

covered: Valid Request: TC01, TC15, TC16 cover successful retrieval and schema/order expectations.
Empty Response: TC02 and TC18 cover empty results and empty-database behaviour.
Error cases for missing resources: TC03, TC04, TC18, TC19 cover 404s for missing account/accountEmail and empty DB.
Input validation: TC05, TC06 cover invalid UUID format; TC13 and TC14 cover injection/XSS attempts.
Authorization: TC07 and TC08 cover missing and invalid authentication (401 responses).
Downstream/service errors: TC09 and TC12 cover service unavailability (503) and gateway timeout (504).
Large dataset handling: TC11 covers retrieval when there are a very large number of audit logs and includes a performance expectation.
Query parameters: TC10 covers presence of unexpected/extra query parameters and tolerant behavior.
Regression & backward compatibility: TC15 and TC16 cover ordering and schema compatibility.
Security: TC13 and TC14 include common injection/XSS negative tests.
gaps: Pagination: No test verifies pagination behavior (page,size,limit/offset) or navigation headers for large result sets — TC11 stresses large volume but does not assert pagination.
Pagination response headers/links: No checks for Link, X-Total-Count or other pagination metadata.
Query parameter validation combinations: Only an extra param case exists; no tests for invalid/unsupported query parameters, nor for permitted query filters or sort parameters.
Authorization scopes/roles (403): Tests cover 401 (unauthenticated) but not 403 (authenticated but unauthorized / insufficient permissions).
Rate limiting / throttling: No tests simulate multiple rapid requests to validate rate limiting, throttling responses (e.g., 429) or retry headers.
Caching behavior and headers: No checks for ETag, Last-Modified, Cache-Control, or conditional GET behavior (304).
Response header validation: Aside from Content-Type in TC01/TC02, there are no assertions for other important headers (Cache-Control, Retry-After, Retry metadata on 503/504, correlation IDs).
Schema edge-cases: No tests for partially populated AuditLog objects, missing optional fields, or unexpected additional fields (robustness of schema validation).
Internationalization / character encoding: No tests for unicode or special characters in audit log fields.
Rate/performance SLOs beyond TC11: Only a single performance expectation in TC11; no load or stress tests defined.
Error message consistency and structure: While many scenarios assert an error message string, there are no assertions about error payload structure (error code, type, details) across responses.
recommendations: Add explicit pagination tests: include page/limit (or offset/limit) requests, verify paging headers or link relations, and test boundary pages (first, last, empty).
Add tests for pagination metadata and header semantics (Link, X-Total-Count, next/prev links) and conditional requests using ETag/If-None-Match to assert 304 behavior.
Include authorization role tests that exercise 403 responses for authenticated users who lack permission to read audit logs.
Add rate-limiting/throttling tests that issue many requests in short time and assert 429 responses and Retry-After headers where applicable.
Add caching header checks (ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified) and conditional GET tests to validate correct caching behavior and freshness semantics.
Expand query-parameter coverage: test invalid/unsupported query parameters, filter/sort parameter combinations if supported, and boundary values for numeric parameters.
Add response-header validations across success and error responses (Content-Type, correlation-id/request-id, Retry-After for 503/504).
Add schema robustness tests: AuditLog entries with missing optional fields, unexpected extra fields, very long string fields, and unicode characters to validate encoding and schema validation.
Standardize and assert error response structure: include tests that validate consistent error JSON structure (code, message, details) instead of only matching message substrings.
Add load/performance tests beyond single large-case TC11: run moderate concurrency tests to assert SLOs and detect regressions under load.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/invoiceItems/{invoiceItemId}/tags - Remove tags from invoice item

covered: Valid Deletion: Multiple success scenarios (full removal, partial removal via tagDef, no-op when tagDef empty) cover expected successful DELETE behavior and the 204 response requirement.
Empty Response: Scenario covers invoice items with no tags and asserts an empty response body and 204.
Query Parameters: Many permutations are covered — valid tagDef, empty tagDef, malformed tagDef, very large tagDef lists, extra/unexpected query parameters.

Header Handling: Required X-Killbill-CreatedBy header presence and absence are tested; optional headers X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment are tested, including special character / XSS payload cases.
Error Responses: Invalid invoiceItemId format (400) and non-existent invoice item (404) are covered as specified in the story.
Authentication: Invalid/expired token scenario (401) is present.
Service Unavailability: Service down/unreachable scenario (503) is present.
Concurrency/Performance: High-concurrency performance test is included to surface race conditions and throughput issues.
Integration/Regression: Tests for dependent service unavailability (audit logging) and a regression case for special characters in comments are present.
gaps: Authorization granularity: No explicit test for forbidden/insufficient-permissions (403) — e.g., authenticated user without permission to modify tags.

Soft-delete semantics: No tests verify whether tag removals are soft-deleted (audit trail, historical visibility) versus hard-deleted; acceptance notes mention audit/integration but not soft-delete behavior verification.

Race conditions for concurrent conflicting operations: TC17 covers high concurrency broadly but lacks specific conflict scenarios — e.g., simultaneous delete and add of the same tag, or delete by two users leading to expected idempotency/consistency checks.
Rate limiting/throttling: No focused tests for rate limiting responses (e.g., 429) or behavior under sustained high request rates beyond a single performance scenario.
Caching / HTTP semantics: No tests for caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control) or conditional requests behavior — even if less applicable to DELETE, responses might still include headers.

Response body schema for errors: Tests assert presence of error messages, but there is no verification of structured error schema/fields (code, type, message, timestamp) to ensure consistent API contract.

Boundary conditions for query length/URL length: TC14 mentions large number of tagDef values but there is no explicit test for URL length limits or server handling of query-string size limits, which can produce 414 or 413.
Idempotency semantics: No explicit tests confirming that repeated identical DELETE requests remain idempotent (204 each time) or return an appropriate status.
Logging/audit verification: While integration-unavailable is covered, there is no positive test that audit logging entries are created when available (i.e., end-to-end audit verification).
Negative tests for malformed headers beyond X-Killbill-CreatedBy missing/XSS: e.g., excessively long header values, non-UTF8, or prohibited characters not covered.
recommendations: Add an authenticated-but-forbidden (403) test to validate authorization/ACL behavior for users lacking tag-modify permission.

Add soft-delete / audit verification tests: when audit logging is available, assert that an audit record is created with createdBy/reason/comment and that tag history can be retrieved if soft-deletes are expected.
Expand concurrency tests with conflict scenarios: simulate simultaneous add+delete and two concurrent deletes to validate idempotency, locking, and lack of data corruption.
Add explicit rate-limiting tests (sustained high request rate) to assert 429 or other throttling behavior and ensure graceful degradation.
Add tests for response and request size limits: exercise very large tagDef lists to trigger and assert 413/414 and document system limits.
Verify error response schema: assert structured error fields (code/type/message) and consistency across 400/401/404/500 responses.
Add idempotency tests: repeat the same DELETE and assert consistent, documented behavior (e.g., subsequent deletes still return 204 or a specific status).
Add positive audit/logging integration test to ensure dependent services record deletion events when available (complements TC19 which covers unavailability).
Include tests for malformed/oversized headers and non-UTF8 payloads to harden header validation (complements XSS tests).

Document which HTTP headers (Cache-Control/ETag) are expected on DELETE responses and add tests if applicable; if not applicable, add a negative assertion that cache headers are not present to avoid client confusion.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/admin/cache/tenants - Invalidates Caches per tenant level

covered: Valid Deletion: TC01, TC09, TC11 validate successful deletion and idempotency (204) for tenant cache invalidation.
Authorization: TC02 and TC03 cover missing and invalid authentication paths (expecting 401).
Non-Existent Resource: TC04 covers tenant-not-found behavior (404).
Server Errors: TC05, TC06, and TC14 cover internal error, service unavailable, and timeout/gateway scenarios (500, 503, 504).
Malformed Input / Validation: TC07 addresses unsupported parameters / bad request handling (400).
Security: TC08 tests header-based injection attempts and expects 400/403.
Concurrency / Race Conditions: TC10 covers concurrent DELETE requests and checks for race-condition safety and performance under load.
Integration / Downstream Effects: TC12 verifies that dependent services observe the invalidation (integration testing concern).
State Variations: TC13 covers partially populated caches being fully invalidated.
Regression: TC11 ensures previously fixed bugs remain fixed (regression test).
gaps: Produces / Content-Type: The Jira story explicitly notes "Produces: application/json" but none of the scenarios assert response Content-Type or behavior when 204 has no body vs JSON content-type.

Request Body / Payload: The story declares request body N/A; however, there are no tests asserting that a sent body is rejected or ignored (TC07 covers extra parameters but not explicit body-with-DELETE behavior).

Tenant Context Validation: While tenant context is mentioned in Background and some scenarios set a non-existent tenant, there are no negative tests validating missing or malformed tenant-context headers/token formats (e.g., header present but invalid format leading to 400/401/403).
Authorization Scope / Roles: Tests check authentication success/failure, but they do not verify authorization levels/roles (e.g., authenticated non-admin user should get 403).
Response Semantics for 204: Tests assert empty body on success, but do not assert that response headers (e.g., Content-Length, Content-Type) are correct or compliant with spec.
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests cover rate limiting or behavior under extreme request rates beyond performance/concurrency.
Caching Headers & Client Caching: No scenarios validate cache-related HTTP headers (ETag, Cache-Control) or whether responses are cacheable by clients.
Soft-Delete / Partial Failure Semantics: No tests check partial success when some internal cache partitions succeed and others fail (how partial failures are reported).
Observability / Metrics: No checks for logging, audit trail, or metrics (important for admin ops and diagnosing impacts described in notes).
Authorization Errors Beyond 401: No explicit 403 tests (forbidden) for authenticated but unauthorized users.
recommendations: Add assertions for response headers on success and error cases: Content-Type (application/json) and appropriate Content-Length or absence of body for 204.
Add tests for authenticated-but-not-admin users expecting 403 (verify authorization/roles, not just authentication).
Add negative tests for missing or malformed tenant-context header/token to clarify 400 vs 401/404 behavior.
Add tests for request bodies sent with DELETE (ensure they are ignored or rejected per API contract) and for unsupported payload content types.
Add tests for partial invalidation scenarios and clear error reporting when some cache partitions fail (ensure API communicates partial failure vs full failure).
Add rate-limiting/throttling tests to validate behavior under sustained high request rates beyond single concurrency test (TC10).
Verify caching-related HTTP headers (ETag, Cache-Control) and client-side caching semantics where applicable.
Include tests to validate observability/audit requirements: that admin actions are logged/auditable and appropriate metrics are emitted.

Clarify and add tests for produced media type: even if 204 has empty body, include a test that the response Content-Type is consistent with "Produces: application/json" or that the API omits Content-Type when empty per spec.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: PUT /1.0/kb/accounts/{childAccountId}/transferCredit - Move a given child credit to the parent level

covered: Valid Request: TC01 and TC02 verify successful transfer and correct 204 response for normal flows.
Header validation: Required header X-Killbill-CreatedBy is tested (TC01, TC02, TC06) and optional headers X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment are covered (TC02).
Missing / malformed inputs: Malformed childAccountId (TC07) and missing required header (TC06) are covered.
Non-existing resources: Non-existent child and parent account cases are covered (TC04, TC05, TC12).
Error handling for insufficient credit: TC03 checks 400 for zero/insufficient credit.
Authorization: Unauthorized access scenario is present (TC10).
Robustness / security: Injection/malicious header payload validation is covered (TC11).
Concurrency & race conditions: Concurrent requests and double-transfer/regression are covered (TC14, TC16).
Operational resilience: Server unavailable scenario is present (TC09).
Performance: High-scale performance/response time for large DB is included (TC13).
gaps: Exact transfer amount and accounting details not validated: Tests assert balances change but do not validate the exact numeric amount moved (source of ambiguity because API has no request body to specify amount).
Response body/content expectations on 204: No explicit test verifies that a 204 response contains an empty body and correct Content-Type / response headers (spec mentions produces application/json).
Audit/log recording beyond reason/comment: TC02 checks reason/comment, but there is no verification of audit metadata (who/when/what) or storage semantics.
500 / server-side failures: No test explicitly simulates internal server error (500) or DB failures besides network/unavailability (TC09 covers 503/network but not 500).
Rate limiting / throttling: No tests for rate limits or API throttling behavior.

Idempotency/duplicate requests semantics beyond concurrency: Duplicate or repeated identical requests (beyond TC16) and client retry behavior are not explicitly covered (e.g., idempotency headers, retry-after).
Edge cases with parent constraints: No tests for parent account state constraints (e.g., parent account closed, suspended, or with credit limits), or business rules preventing transfer.
Boundary numeric tests: No tests for very large credit amounts, fractional currencies, rounding, or overflow conditions.
Content negotiation / headers: No tests for Content-Type/Accept headers or behavior when unsupported headers/content types are used.
Logging/observability: No tests validating presence of correlation IDs, audit trail IDs, or that reason/comment appear in returned audit endpoints.
recommendations: Add explicit numeric assertions for the exact amount transferred: create pre/post balances and assert child.balance decreased by X and parent.balance increased by X (define X clearly in test data).
Add tests to assert response semantics for 204: empty body, Content-Type (if any), and any relevant headers per API contract (e.g., Location, audit ids).
Simulate and assert 500 Internal Server Error paths: inject DB failures or mock service-layer exceptions to ensure 500 responses and meaningful error payloads.
Add rate-limiting tests: hammer the endpoint and assert 429 or throttling behavior and presence of retry-after headers where applicable.
Cover parent account state constraints: tests for parent suspended/closed/with transfer restrictions should return appropriate errors (400/403/409 as per business rules).
Add boundary and numeric tests: very large credits, fractional values, zero-plus-epsilon, and currency rounding to detect overflow/precision issues.
Expand duplicate submission/idempotency tests: verify client retries and duplicate requests behavior (e.g., idempotency keys) beyond concurrency tests.
Verify audit/logging storage: after TC02-like runs, query audit/log endpoints (or DB) to assert reason/comment, creator, and timestamp are recorded correctly.
Add header/content-negotiation tests: missing/invalid Accept or Content-Type, and behavior with unsupported media types.
Add tests for observability headers: pass/expect correlation IDs and verify they flow into logs/audit where applicable.

results.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/export/{accountId} - Export account data

covered: Valid Request: Multiple success scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC08, TC13, TC14, TC15) verify successful exports with required/optional headers, large payloads, concurrency and regression/backwards-compatibility checks.
Empty Response / No Data: TC07 verifies behavior when the account database is empty (404).
Input Validation: TC04, TC11 validate malformed/malicious accountId formats returning 400.
Non-Existing Resource: TC05 covers 404 when account is not found.
Required Headers: TC01/TC02/TC03 validate presence/absence of required header X-Killbill-CreatedBy and proper 400 handling.
Error Handling / Service Failures: TC10 (export service unavailable -> 500), TC09 and TC17 (slow downstream/timeout -> timeouts and configured limits / 504) cover server/dependency error behaviors.
HTTP Method Handling: TC16 verifies unsupported HTTP method returns 405.
Authentication/Authorization: TC18 checks unauthorized access returns 401 (if auth required).
Content-Type and Response Body: Many scenarios assert application/octet-stream and that the response is a valid export archive and size/time constraints (TC01, TC02, TC08, TC09).
Edge cases: TC12 checks missing accountId in path; TC06 checks extra unsupported headers are tolerated.
gaps: Pagination: No test covers pagination or chunked listing behavior for large multi-account exports — the guidelines expect pagination checks for large datasets.
Query Parameters: The story and feature have no tests for query parameters (filters, format options) — none validated.
Caching Behavior: No scenarios validate caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control), conditional GET, or revalidation behavior.
Rate Limiting / Throttling: There is no explicit test for rate limiting (429 responses) or behavior under sustained high request rates; TC13 tests concurrency but not rate-limiting thresholds.
Authorization granularity: While TC18 covers missing/invalid token -> 401, there are no tests for forbidden access (403) or role-based authorization scopes.
Response Metadata: No tests verify headers like Content-Disposition, Content-Length, Content-Encoding (compression), or streaming behavior (e.g., chunked transfer)

Export Format/Integrity: Tests assert "valid export archive" but do not validate archive format details (compression type, file structure, checksums) or whether the exported content includes all expected entities.
